zup.name: Senior Software Engineer - Zup Innovation
zup.description:
I work in the insurance area of ‚Äã‚Äãa client in the banking/financial sector and I work with microservices in Java Spring Boot and NodeJS/TypeScript applications in Lambda.
Project 1: Increase the number of insurance proposals contracted through scheduled reminders. I designed the architecture, brought it to the team for discussion and then developed the solution. In the period of 1 year, 17 thousand proposals were formalized thanks to the reminders. Technologies involved: TypeScript, NodeJS, Java, Apache Kafka, AWS Lambda, AWS ECS, AWS EventBridge Scheduler, AWS SNS, AWS SQS, AWS DynamoDB.
Project 2: Extract insurance proposal data from our database and save it in a partitioned S3 bucket so that the data and analytics team can perform SQL queries in Amazon Athena. The result of this project is the democratization of data and the possibility of discovering new insights about the business. Technologies involved: AWS DynamoDB, DynamoDB Streams, AWS Lambda, AWS Step Functions, AWS EventBridge Scheduler, AWS Glue, Apache Spark, Python, Terraform, CI/CD, Grafana, Prometheus.
Project 3: Enable the squad to test new things in the development environment. The context of this problem is that we can only test new things after moving them to the staging environment, and this is not ideal. My job was to review the squad's entire microservices architecture and put together a plan to adjust all applications and make them work in the development environment. The result of this project was an increase in the squad's productivity as it was able to iterate faster on new developments.

google.name: Software Engineer - Google
google.description:
I worked within the Google Search product area as a software engineer maintaining Data Engineering solutions (e.g. Google Flume, Google Dataflow, Apache Flink) that process billions of logs every day and help Google evaluate its own products through satisfaction surveys sent directly to real users (e.g. Google Opinion Rewards App). Technologies involved: C++, RPC/gRPC, Protocol Buffers, Blaze/Bazel, Java, Python and relational databases.
I also worked on some additional projects:
Project 1: I was responsible for creating scheduled jobs that process billions of data points and generate tables that are later used to create dashboards that help monitor the health of an internal system. All technologies involved are internal.
Project 2: I was responsible for collaborating on the design of a feature to enable internal users to create UI components through configuration files and I developed the front end code necessary to support this architecture. Technologies involved: Google Cloud, React, GraphQL, TypeScript, JavaScript and NodeJS.
Project 3: I worked as front and back end developing UI components that help internal users build satisfaction surveys. Technologies involved: Google Cloud, C++, RPC/gRPC, Protocol Buffers, Blaze/Bazel, Kotlin, TypeScript, React, GraphQL, NodeJS and relational databases.

accenture.name: Application Development Analyst - Accenture
accenture.description:
Project 1: I was assigned to understand a need of the SAP team and create a solution from scratch, including layout, frontend (React), backend (Node), database (Postgres) and infrastructure on AWS (EC2, S3 and RDS).
Project 2: I worked as a React front-end technical lead. Our mission was to improve the accessibility of several websites of a large healthcare company in Brazil. This involves testing screen readers, color contrast and other things described in the WCAG standards. I helped the team both in the development of tasks and in the organization of the project (Git Flow, Code Review, CI/CD Pipelines, Technical Refinement).

Participation in 2 development projects.
Project 1: A Ruby on Rails API with infrastructure on AWS (EC2, RDS and S3 with video upload), was the biggest challenge, as in 2 weeks I had to take over the project alone, and I was responsible for the infrastructure on AWS, the backend development, deploys and updates to the production database.
Project 2: A Node Serverless project using AWS Lambda, was an authentication integration via SAML 2.0. I was responsible for a good part of the project cycle: conception, technical meetings with the client, development, automated tests and deployment.
